name: Using a local repository
info: making a repository and commiting changes to it
content:
#git local repository is a repository on your local machine

#the root directory of your local repo
cd /path/to/your/exsisting/code

#initialize git to make this directory into a repo
git init

#if you wish to get a exisiting repo in your current folder 
git clone <repo url>

#adding new files to your repo
git add <file>

#adding all files to a repo (including subdirectories)
git add .

#commiting your files to the repo
#this means you add the changed content to the repo (if you change the file or you add it initially)
git commit 

#if you wish to add a message the the commit
git commit -m "your message"

name: Uploading to a remote repository
info: commiting changes to a remote repo
content:
#initial remote configurations

#first you need to have a local repository of your content

#then add the remote repo to your local repo
#be sure you are in the right directory
#the remote url is often the github link followed by .git
#the remote name is something you give it usually origin
git remote add <remote_name> <remote_repo_url>

#after you have made the wanted changes you need to upload your content to the remote repo
#remote name is the name you defined earlier 
#and local branch name is the branch you currently are editing see further on how to do this
git push -u <remote_name> <local_branch_name>

name: Editing user settings for git
info: How to edit your git settings
content:
#define the author name
#use --local for changing the author name on local repo's
git config --global user.name <name>

#define the user e-mail
git config --local user.email <email>

#change the default editor (standard is vim)
git config --system core.editor <editor>

#change global settings
git config --global --edit

name: Git status
info: Get the status of your current git repo
content:
#check the status of your local repo
git status

#this gives you information of your repo
#like uncommited files (in case you forgot to commit them)

#uefull parameters

#check the status of the specified branch
git status -b <branch>

#give a short output
#usefull to quickly check what needs to be commited
git status -s

#extra information is displayed
git status -v

name: Git status
info: Get the status of your current git repo
content:
#to create a new branch
git checkout -b <branch>

#to change to the new branch
git checkout <branch>

#to push the branch to a remote repo
git push <remote_name> <branch>

#get a list of all the branches
git branch

#default branch is master

#delete a branch
git branch -D <branch>

#delete a branch on github
git push origin :<branch>
